awd_titl_txt: A Fully Discrete Framework for the Adaptive Solution of Inverse Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Inverse problems like parameter estimation, data assimilation, optimal
engineering design, and optimal control of large scale systems governed by
partial differential equations,  are of considerable importance in many
fields including atmospheric science and oceanography, aerospace
engineering, and fluid and structural mechanics.

State-of-the-art solvers for large scale partial differential equations
adaptively refine the time step and the mesh, and adjust the computational
pattern according to the features of the solution. Adaptivity is necessary
to control the numerical errors introduced by temporal and spatial
discretizations and to preserve the qualitative features of the solution
(e.g., avoid the formation of spurious wiggles). In contrast, most inverse
problems to date have been solved using non-adaptive methods (e.g., fixed
grids and timesteps).

This project develops a fully discrete framework for solving inverse
problems in the context of adaptive models. The framework fills the gap
between the state-of-the-art adaptive methods used in (forward)
simulations and the computational tools currently available for the
solution of inverse problems. The specific research objectives are to
develop discrete algorithms for inverse problems with models that employ
refinement of the spatial discretization, and adaptive time stepping, to
guarantee that the discrete inversion process leads to convergent
numerical approximations, and to control the accuracy of the inverse
solution.

The results of this work are general algorithms and methodologies that
will advance the field of inverse problems by developing the capability to
adapt time steps, grid sizes, and computational patterns, such as to
control the quality and accuracy of the inverse solutions.  These results
have the potential to impact any mature
field which relies on adaptive simulations, such as data assimilation in
atmospheric sciences, oceanography, and environmental sciences; optimal
control of flows, and optimal engineering design.

The algorithmic and software tools developed during this research will be
largely disseminated through specialized journals and conferences. This
project provides an excellent opportunity for training graduate students in
the areas  of inverse problems and adaptive computations.

por.por_cntn:
Inverse problems in science and engineering use information from measurements of real world (observations of the effects) to better understand the underlying physical phenomena (calculate the causes). Inverse problems like parameter estimation, data assimilation, optimal engineering design, and optimal control of large scale systems governed by partial differential equations, are of considerable importance in many fields including atmospheric science and oceanography, aerospace engineering, and fluid and structural mechanics, to name just a few.  Our main interest is data assimilation, the process to optimally fuse information from observational data and computer models in order to learn more about the physical system under consideration. In a variational approach the data assimilation problem is posed as an inverse problem, where parameters are adjusted such that the model predictions best fit the observations.

Today the state-of-the-art solvers for large scale partial differential equations adaptively refine the time steps and mesh sizes, the numerical approximation, and the reduced order basis onto which the dynamics model is projected, in order to control numerical errors introduced by various approximations and to preserve the qualitative features of the solution (e.g., avoid the formation of spurious wiggles). In contrast, most inverse problems to date have been solved using non-adaptive methods. The results of this research fill the gap between the state-of-the-art methods used in (forward) simulation and the computational tools currently available for the solution of inverse problems.

Intellectual Merit. A major challenge in solving inverse problems with partial differential equations is the very large computational cost to solution. In forward simulations one approach to reduce the computational times is via reduced order modeling, where a surrogate model that captures the most important dynamical features is constructed. A second major challenge is that the standard approach to solving discrete inverse problems lacks the mechanisms necessary to control the accuracy of the inverse solution. This research addresses both these challenges. We have developed and applied a theoretical framework for a general reduced order variational inverse problems, with application to data assimilation. We proved that two ingredients have to characterize every projection based reduced data assimilation system: consistency of the reduced order optimality conditions with respect to the full optimality conditions, and accurate surrogates for both the forward and adjoint dynamical models. Numerical experiments show that a hybrid reduced data assimilation system is approximately ten times faster than the full space data assimilation system with optimality solutions presenting similar degree of accuracy and using small space mesh resolutions. We also developed a computational complexity analysis of different type of reduced order models which is a useful tool for selecting the fastest surrogate approach corresponding to a particular problem. We have developed and applied a new methodology for time-implicit reduced order models. This methodology is based on a novel approach to compute reduced order sparse matrices, and the results revealed accurate and computationally inexpensive approximations unlike the current discrete empirical interpolation method and matrix discrete empirical interpolation method.  During the course of this research we have developed new sampling approaches to solve probabilistic inverse problems. They are able to solve non-Gaussian probabilistic inverse problems, a highly important and challenging quest. We constructed samplers that employ the reduced order model surrogates such as to greatly reduce the computational time to solution.  We have also demonstrated the application of Machine learning techniques to the construction of parametric reduced order models, realizing adaptability in the parameter space.

 Broader Impact. The results of this work are general algorithms and methodologies for solving inverse problems. These tools will potentially benefit many fields in science and engineering from numerical weather prediction, to discovery and mapping of oil and gas reservoirs, to optimal design of aircraft such as to enhance flight performance and fuel economy. The algorithmic and software tools developed during this research have been largely disseminated through specialized journals and conferences. One postdoctoral researcher, two doctoral students (including one female), one master student, and one undergraduate student have been trained in the areas of inverse problems, reduced order modeling, machine learning, and mathematical software development.
